description: From Middle English avisen (“to perceive, consider, inform”), from Old French aviser, from avis, or from Late Latin advisō, from ad + visō, from Latin videō (“to see”), visum (“past participle of videō”). See also advice.

verbs.description: advise (third-person singular simple present advises, present participle advising, simple past and past participle advised)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To give advice to; to offer an opinion to, as worthy or expedient to be followed.
examples: The dentist advised me to brush three times a day.
The lawyer advised me to drop the case, since there was no chance of winning.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To recommend; to offer as advice.
examples: The dentist advised brushing three times a day.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To give information or notice to; to inform or counsel; — with of before the thing communicated.
examples: We were advised of the risk.

entries.meaning: (obsolete, transitive) To look at, watch; to see.
(Scotland, law) To deliver judgment after a case has been reserved for further consideration.
